I think you're just trying to troll, but I like talking about the subject, so I'll give you a serious answer for why I think the technology is useful

>helicopter taxis have already been a thing since the 70s because rich people will pay a ton of money to avoid big city traffic
>electricity is cheaper than gas
>electric motors are much, much easier to maintain than piston or turbine
>engines are less likely to break, removing a potentially fatal point of failure
>most designs have multiple, redundant motors and blades, meaning that losing a blade or engine is an inconvenience rather than a near certain crash
>fly by wire reduces the chance of piloting error or stability problems, which are another key cause of accidents for helicopters
>analysts are saying that eVTOLs would be about as energy intensive per mile as an electric car, which is ridiculously good for something that can fly at 200 miles an hour
>noise reduction is considerable

When you put it all together, you get something with dramatically lower O&M costs, better safety, and just overall more convenience to actually implement. I suspect that it will always be a luxury rather than a commonly used utility, but it'll be incredibly cool to be able to take a flying uber and get downtown from the airport in five minutes.

There is a counterintuitive idea in road systems where a shortcut slows down the whole system, as any one car has no incentive to go a longer route, but if the shortcut is closed most peoples travel time will be decreased.
The same is probably true of transit systems, but is probably harder to observe, predict and model. The slowdowns are probably in transfers being slowed down by congested hallways ect.
Also when do you have too many lines? When you don't have the money to run them at good frequencies. Could you close a line and increase the frequency on other lines?
This is the logic of many small city bus systems, where there are too many bus routes, but non of them are frequent enough to be useful. Spending the same money on fewer routes would bring better service to the whole system and possibly make it self-sufficient.

com:
Oval chainrings thread since the last one 404'd.

So I've learned another reason why they're not popular: they really, really do not tolerate crosschaining. Like half my cassette is unbearable to ride in when I'm in the small ring. The mechanic at my LBS said it's a combination of the chainring being slightly thicker than the Shimano brand chainring, and the fact that the tallest part of the oval extends further into the chainline (which I imagine would be like if I got a 52t chainring, but I've never had anything higher than a 50).

They do make it a lot easier to stay in the big ring while climbing, so that somewhat makes up for the annoyance, but round chainrings are definitely not a conspiracy to make you slow.

Without looking at Australian rail freight for more than 10 seconds, my impression of it is that it's mostly very long trains with heavy bulk goods. That's practically a no-brainer to put on trains, and even the worst rail freight systems in the world would still get the heavy bulk.
I personally look a lot at how well rail competes with road when I gauge the success of rail freight, because a punctual, reliable and commercially viable rail freight system attracts a lot of goods that otherwise would be shipped by road. With that in mind, ton-km (yes, I do argue against myself too) isn't an accurate metric of how well rail freight performs in a given country, as the heavy bulk goods that goes on rail anyway will inflate that number.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1870921
Did you do the math? graf zeppelin ii carried 70 passengers and 40 crew members, and used 65000kg of diesel fuel (so 79000l) for a 16500km range. That's around 479 liters spent every 100 km, or a 6.84 l/100km fuel consumption per passenger - which sounds high compared to current aircraft (2.27 to 3.76 l/100km), but that fails to consider that every passenger had it's own cabin while modern airlines try to cram as many people as possible for a given payload.

Using the 787 as a reference, that can carry a maximum of 440 people for a 57277 kg payload - as the graf zeppelin ii can carry a 37000 kg payload, that would mean that given the same passenger density it would have 284 seats, and consume 1,69 l/100km per passenger. Argue all you want that you can't cram that many people in trips that take days instead of hours, but that still means that 1930's technology beats any new passenger plane in terms of raw fuel efficiency...

Once again, airships have quite a few problems (travel time, construction costs, lack of climb ability, sheer size), but fuel consumption isn't one of them.

The range these airships have compared to the amount of fuel they carry already indicates they were working rather efficiently.>>1862751

If you do the math, you'll also see that at top speed (thus peak inneficiency) the graf zeppelin ii needa 3,56 Mw of power to attain 135 km/h, which amounts to around 78 kn of thrust or 7600 kgf if you assume a propeller efficiency of 80%.

Compare that to 232 000 kg of gross lift, and it adds up to a 30:1 lift to drag ratio. Given the way parasitic drag works, going twice as fast would reduce it to a 7:1, but at half speed it improves to 120:1, so airships are fuel efficient within their operating speeds even by modern standards.

skate shoes and bike shoes are pretty much opposites. skate shoes have a lot of padding and a thin, flexible sole for "boardfeel". they can also have reinforced toe area and stiffness/material around the ankle for support. bike shoes don't have as much padding, and have a stiffer sole to support the foot and make better power transfer when pedaling.
